lines.text: Sennet. Enter KING RICHARD III, in pomp, crowned; BUCKINGHAM, CATESBY, a page, and others

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: My gracious sovereign?

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Give me thy hand. Thus high, by thy advice And thy assistance, is King Richard seated; But shall we wear these honours for a day? Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?
Here he ascendeth his throne

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Still live they and for ever may they last!

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: O Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Say on, my loving lord.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: True, noble prince.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: O bitter consequence, That Edward still should live! 'True, noble prince!' Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull: Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead; And I would have it suddenly perform'd. What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Your grace may do your pleasure.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Tut, tut, thou art all ice, thy kindness freezeth: Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord Before I positively herein: I will resolve your grace immediately.
Exit

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: [Aside to a stander by] The king is angry: see, he bites the lip.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: I will converse with iron-witted fools And unrespective boys: none are for me That look into me with considerate eyes: High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect. Boy!

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: My lord?

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold Would tempt unto a close exploit of death?

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: My lord, I know a discontented gentleman, Whose humble means match not his haughty mind: Gold were as good as twenty orators, And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: What is his name?

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: I partly know the man: go, call him hither. The deep-revolving witty Buckingham No more shall be the neighbour to my counsel: Hath he so long held out with me untired, And stops he now for breath? How now! what news with you?
Exit Page
Enter STANLEY

lines.speaker: stanley
lines.text: My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea Where he abides.
Stands apart

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Catesby!

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: My lord?

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Rumour it abroad That Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die: I will take order for her keeping close. Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman, Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter: The boy is foolish, and I fear not him. Look, how thou dream'st! I say again, give out That Anne my wife is sick and like to die: About it; for it stands me much upon, To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me. I must be married to my brother's daughter, Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass. Murder her brothers, and then marry her! Uncertain way of gain! But I am in So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin: Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye. Is thy name Tyrrel?
Exit CATESBY
Re-enter Page, with TYRREL

lines.speaker: tyrrel
lines.text: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Art thou, indeed?

lines.speaker: tyrrel
lines.text: Prove me, my gracious sovereign.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

lines.speaker: tyrrel
lines.text: Ay, my lord; But I had rather kill two enemies.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies, Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers Are they that I would have thee deal upon: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

lines.speaker: tyrrel
lines.text: Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear: There is no more but so: say it is done, And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.
Whispers

lines.speaker: tyrrel
lines.text: 'Tis done, my gracious lord.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?

lines.speaker: tyrrel
lines.text: Ye shall, my Lord.
Exit
Re-enter BUCKINGHAM

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind The late demand that you did sound me in.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Well, let that pass. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: I hear that news, my lord.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Stanley, he is your wife's son well, look to it.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise, For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd; The earldom of Hereford and the moveables The which you promised I should possess.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Stanley, look to your wife; if she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: What says your highness to my just demand?

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: As I remember, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king, When Richmond was a little peevish boy. A king, perhaps, perhaps,--

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: My lord!

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: How chance the prophet could not at that time Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: My lord, your promise for the earldom,--

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Richmond! When last I was at Exeter, The mayor in courtesy show'd me the castle, And call'd it Rougemont: at which name I started, Because a bard of Ireland told me once I should not live long after I saw Richmond.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: My Lord!

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Ay, what's o'clock?

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: I am thus bold to put your grace in mind Of what you promised me.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Well, but what's o'clock?

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Upon the stroke of ten.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Well, let it strike.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Why let it strike?

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation. I am not in the giving vein to-day.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.

lines.speaker: king richard the third
lines.text: Tut, tut, Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.
Exeunt all but BUCKINGHAM

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Is it even so? rewards he my true service With such deep contempt made I him king for this? O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!
Exit
